did.unittitle: The Bailey Collection

bioghist.p: The antiquary, John Eglington Bailey, was born at Edgbaston, Birmingham, on 13 February 1840, the son of Charles Bailey and Mary Elizabeth Bailey, daughter of John Eglington of Ashbourne. His family removed to Lancashire during his childhood, and he was educated at Boteler’s Grammar School, Warrington, and at Owen's College, Manchester. He was employed at the counting-house of the Ralli Brothers, Manchester, where he remained until 1886.

Bailey was a prolific author: he published 420 articles, and also a number of books covering a range of subjects from Lancashire and Cheshire topography to the lives of seventeenth-century divines. He learned Pitman’s shorthand, and contributed articles to shorthand, manuscript, or lithograph magazines and bibliographical journals, such asShorthand(1882),Retrospective Review(1874), andThe Bibliographer(1882). Bailey contributed articles to newspapers and magazines such asOwen’s College Magazine(1868, 1870-1, 1878, 1880); theManchester Guardian Local Notes and Queries(1874-7); theManchester City News Notes and Queries(1879, 1884-6); thePreston Guardian Sketches in Local History(1875-7, 1879); and theLeigh Chronicle(1878-9), amongst others. Bailey was a frequent contributor to the journals of theManchester Literary Club(1875-9, 1881-5) andManchester Field Naturalists’ Society(1878-9, 1882) as well as to various other journals, such asNotes and Queries(1864, 1869, 1873, 1874-86);Gloucestershire Notes and Queries(1879, 1881-4, 1886-8); and alsoThe Western Antiquary(1883), and the quarterly review concerned with Pagan and early-Christian antiquities,The Reliquary (1884).

His interest in the antiquities of Lancashire and Cheshire led to his contributions to a number of publications:Local Gleanings(1875, 1877-80);Cheshire Sheaf(1878-83);Lancashire and Cheshire Antiquarian Notes(1884); theJournal of the Chester Archaeological and Historic Society(1887); and theTransactions of the Lancashire and Cheshire Antiquarian Society(1886-7). HisInventories of goods in the churches and chapels of Lancashire, taken in the year A.D. 1552, was published in two parts by the Chetham Society (1879, 1888), and the final part was completed and edited by Henry Fishwick (1902). In 1881, he became the founder and editor of the monthly antiquarian magazine,The Palatine Note-Book(1881-5). He also contributed to theEncyclopaedia Britannicawith articles on ‘Cryptography’ (1877) and ‘Thomas Fuller’ (1879), and also to theDictionary of National Biography(1885) with articles on a number of divines and antiquaries. Bailey also edited Henry Clarke’sThe School Candidates: A Prosaic Burlesque(Manchester, 1877), and theDiary for the years 1595-1601 of Dr John Dee, Warden of Manchester from 1595-1608(1880). He also wroteManchester al Mondo: A Contemplation of Death and Immortality(London: Pickering, 1880), and co-authored (with C.E. Banks) a biography ofColonel Alexander Rigby (Portland, Maine, USA, 1885).

However, Bailey’s life-long interest was the work of the ecclesiastical historian, Thomas Fuller (1608-61). His lecture on Fuller to the Manchester Phonographic Union, was printed in thePopular Lecturer(1864). He devoted his holidays to visiting Fuller’s places of residence, and Bailey’s most important contribution was hisLife of Thomas Fuller(Manchester: T. J. Day, 1874). His scholarship was recognised by his election as a Fellow of the Society of Antiquaries of London. Bailey had intended to issue a two-volume edition of Fuller’s sermons, but this project was never completed, and Bailey edited only one of Fuller’s sermons:A Sermon of Reformation (Manchester: T.J. Day, 1875). Bailey’s intended project was later completed and edited by W.E.A. Axon (1891). Bailey amassed a large library of antiquarian and general literature, and also collected numerous works on stenography with a view to writing a history and bibliography of English stenography, but this was another project that was never realised.

He delivered lectures to various literary and local history societies, including the Manchester Literary Club, Urmston and Flixton Literary and Scientific Society, and the Leigh Literary Society. He was also a member of the Chetham Society, serving as a councillor (1876-88) and Honorary Secretary (1882-8), as well as a councillor of the Lancashire and Cheshire Antiquarian Society (1884-9). A member of the Chorlton Road Congregational Church, he also compiled aManual of the Chorlton Road Congregational Church, Manchester (Manchester: James Andrew, 1877). From 1886, illness impaired Bailey’s research and studies, and he died, aged 48, at Etchells, Stockport, Cheshire, on 23 August 1888. He was buried at Stretford Church, Manchester, on 27 August 1888. In 1866, he had married Emma Mills, the second daughter of Samuel Mills of Ardwick, and they had four children.

scopecontent.p: Miscellaneous notes, transcripts, and original documents compiled and collected by John Eglington Bailey (1840-1888) FSA. Some of the notes are in shorthand.

accessrestrict.p: There are no restrictions on access to this collection. Viewing is by prior appointment. Please contact archivist@chethams.org.uk

acqinfo.p: John Eglington Bailey’s personal library was sold by auction at Capes, Dunn & Pilcher, Manchester, from 24 to 30 June 1889, and it is not entirely clear how Chetham’s Library acquired the collection. In June 1889 the Library’s General Purposes Committee authorised the Librarian to spend up to £60 on the purchase of the Bailey manuscripts at the forthcoming sale; however, in a note in the catalogue, John Cree noted, ‘Catalogue of the Manuscripts of the late J. E. Bailey presented to the Chetham Library by R. C. Christie, Chancellor of the Diocese of Manchester’. Presumably, this note refers to Cree’s catalogue and not to the entire Bailey collection, and since there are no details of Christie's donation in the Library records, it thus appears that the Library purchased the Bailey manuscripts but was given Cree’s catalogue in the following year.

did.unittitle: Lancashire Assessment of 1641 and miscellaneous notes
Original manuscript of the 1641 tax assessment for the Manchester area.

scopecontent.p: Incomplete and excludes Manchester itself. 17 documents:
I. Broughton, Kersal, Tetlow.
II. Pendleton.
III. Urmston.
IV. Pilkington.
V. Flixton.
VI. Salford.
VII. Clifton.
VIII. Pendlebury.
IX. Withington, Fallowfield, Rusholme, Moss Side, Didsbury, Levenshulme.
X. Worsley, Swinton, Boothstown, Little Hulton.
XI. Chorton-cum-Hardy.
XII. Haughton.
XIII. Prestwich, Heaton, Heaton-upon-Faughfield, Alkrington, Tonge.
XIV. Chadderton.
XV. Royton.
XVI. Crompton.
XVII. Oldham.
Notes

The assessment was compiled following the Act of Parliament entitled An act for the speedie provision of money for the disbanding of the armies following the peace of the two kingdoms of England and Scotland, August 1641. (Printed version - Wing E 1130.)

Those parts of the manuscript relating to the townships of Oldham, Chadderton, Royton and Crompton were reprinted in Giles Shaw,Annals of Oldham(Oldham, 1904). The entry for Crompton is also reproduced in Elsie Ballard,A Chronicle of Crompton (1967), pp. 34-37.

The work is Lot No. 2445: Names of persons to be assessed in Oldham, Chadderton, Royton, Crompton, Shaw, Prestwich, Pendleton, Pilkington, Chorlton-cum-Hardy, Haughton, Withington, Clifton, Pendlebury, Worsley, Urmston etc. 1641, Original Lists. Catalogue of the valuable and extensive Library of the late John Eglington Bailey …sold by auction, by Capes, Dunn and Pilcher Monday, June 24th 1889 and five following days.

did.unittitle: Miscellaneous notes, transcripts and original documents
Notebook compiled by J. E. Bailey.

list.item: Notebook containing notes on various subjects:
i) ‘Extracts from Torporley Register from MS penes [John] Arden of Stockport, Esq., 1769’: being a list of marriages and burials taken from the parish registers of Tarporley.
ii) ‘Epitaph drawn up at the request of John Kay Hatfeild by me John Watson, Stockport, 1770. (Latin).
iii) ‘Manuscripts penes John Arden of Stockport, Esq., besides those relating to Cheshire’, being a list of manuscripts and pedigrees largely relating to Lancashire.
iv) ‘MS B[oo]k Y[or]ks[hire] families in Watson MSS’ being notes on various families.
v) ‘A short refutation of some cheife pointes in Mr Burne his sermons latelie preached in Manchester’, being a discussion of the sermons of The Rev. William Burne.
vi) ‘Arden MS (continued)’ being a further list of the manuscripts in the possession of John Arden.
a) A copy of the memoryall which Sir Walter Aston the Ambassador of the Kynge of G[rea]t Britayne have his Majestie of Spayne the 29th of July 1624’.

b) A discourse ‘whereby it is endeavoured to prove that it would be lawfull to subscribe to the Engagement of the present powers were usurpers (as is pretended by the Dissenters) and this notwithstanding the Covenant on anie other preingagements’.
c) ‘News from Scotland’, being an account of what passed after the Marquis of Hamilton was returned into England.
d) ‘Contains a pedigree of Marbury’.
e) ‘Dr Abdie Assheton’s letter concerning the Earl of Essex’.
vii) Extracts from the Parish Registers of Prestbury, such as Burials (1562, 1642, 16531721), Weddings (1574-1721), and Christenings (1561-1688).

viii) Copy of a letter from ‘Per: Towneley’, 7 Park St, Westminster, to Charles Blundell, Esq., Ince, Liverpool, dated 15 May 1823. The letter relates to ‘a copy of the extract from the Towneley Mysteries selected for the purpose of presentation to the Roxburgh Club by Mr Douce’.

ix) ‘An Act for repairing and amending the Road leading from the Town of Manchester in the Co[unty] Pal[atine] of Lanc[aster] thro[ugh] the town of Ashton-under-Lyne and the parish of Mottram-[in]-Long[d]endale, and from thence to Salter’s Brook in the co[unty] Pal[atine] of Chester’. The list of trustees includes 93 names.
Act for repairing the road from Manchester to Salter’s Brook with a long list of trustees, 1732.

controlaccess.title: The antiquities of Canterbury. : In two parts. The first part. The antiquities of Canterbury; or a survey of that ancient city, with the suburbs and cathedral, &c. Sought out and published by the industry and good will of William Somner. Of the late Priory of Christ-Church; and of the present Collegiate Church, founded by K. Hen. VIII. With a catalogue of all the Deans and Canons thereof. IV. Of the Monastery of St. Augustin; of the parish-churches, hospitals, and other religious places, that are or have been in or near that city; / enquired into, by Nicholas Battely, Vicar of Beaksborn. Illustrated and adorned with several useful and fair sculptures.

Manorial court rolls relating to Nantwich, Ches

scopecontent.p: This sub-series of court records refer to the court leet, view of frankpledge and court baron for the barony of Nantwich (Wich Malbank), consisting of the townships of Nantwich, Stoke, Aston and Cholmeston. During the medieval period Nantwich was under the jurisdiction of the Abbey of Combermere, but following its dissolution in July 1538 its possessions were forfeit to the crown, and Sir Thomas Foulehurst, the Steward to the Countess of Warwick's Fee, was made Chief Officer of the town. In 1562 Sir Thomas's son, Robert Foulehurst, sold the Fee of the Countess of Warwick to Sir Christopher Hatton. Thus, Sir Christopher Hatton became Lord of the Manor of Nantwich and the townships of Nantwich, Stoke, Aston and Cholmeston became answerable to him. The ancient parishes of Nantwich and Acton in South Cheshire lay within the barony of Nantwich.

Protestation of 1641-2: Lists of the Protestors for the whole of Lancashire

scopecontent.p: 19th century transcripts copied from the originals in the House of Lords Record Office.

In 1641-2 Parliament ordered all males in England and Wales over the age of 18 to take an oath to "live and die for the true Protestant religion, the liberties and rights of subjects, and the privilege of Parliaments". Churchwardens and constables made lists of all who signed and of those who refused to sign. Bailey's transcripts were copied from the originals in the House of Lords Record Office. Bailey described the Manchester list as "perhaps the earliest and completest list of the inhabitants of Manchester that could be found...They form an excellent basis for the calculation of population, and for the study of Lancashire nomenclature; while they are invaluable for historic and genealogical purposes. All the then well-known names of Lancashire men are found in the lists" (J. E. Bailey,Palatine Note-Book, volume I (1880-84), p 80).
Returns have been preserved for the hundreds of Amounderness, Blackburn, Leyland, Salford and West Derby.

list.item: The Manchester section of these transcripts was printed by Bailey inThe Palatine Note-Book, volume 1, 1881, pp 80 et seq.
B. G. Blackwood,The Lancashire Gentry and the Great Rebellion, Chetham Society, 3rd Series vol 25 (1978).
R. Stewart-Brown, The inhabitants of Liverpool from the 14th to the 18th century (Liverpool, 1930).
